    Using netify as an object factory

    Ha Eun Choi, Cassy Dorff, Colin Henry, and Shahryar Minhas

    2022-12-15

    netify_objectFactory.Rmd
    library(devtools)
library(netify)

    Using netify as an object factory

    netify is an object factory. It can take in matrix, array, or list data and build a netlet from scratch. It can also return empty netlet objects that can be filled in later. This can be useful for more complex coding projects that want to integrate network data structures or have access to other functions in the netify package.

    First, let’s start by creating some matrix data. This chunk creates an object with a weighted adjacency matrix structure. Nodes a, b, and c have weighted edges connecting them.

    mat <- matrix( rnorm(9), nrow = 3, ncol = 3, dimnames = list(letters[1:3],letters[1:3]) )
mat
#>             a          b           c
#> a -1.07537435 -1.3191081  0.95826542
#> b  0.86915143 -0.8009156  0.50820268
#> c -0.06747536  0.6507051 -0.01255918

    Now, we can convert this to a netify object by calling the get_netify function. Because the adjacency matrix is weighted, we need to tell the function that the network is weighted by naming the weight variable.

    netlet <- netify(mat, weight = 'the_weight_var')
netlet
#> ✔ Hello, you have created network data, yay!
#> • Symmetric: Yes
#> • Weighted: Yes
#> • Number of Unique Actors: 3
#> • Number of Edges: -0.289107884008562
#> • Number of Time Points: N/A
#> • Average Number of Actors: 3
#> • Nodal Attributes: N/A

    Great! As you can see, we’ve created a netify network object from the adjacency matrix that has all the attributes of a typical netify object set to default values.

    attributes(netlet)
#> $dim
#> [1] 3 3
#> 
#> $dimnames
#> $dimnames[[1]]
#> [1] "a" "b" "c"
#> 
#> $dimnames[[2]]
#> [1] "a" "b" "c"
#> 
#> 
#> $actor_pds
#> $actor_pds[[1]]
#> NULL
#> 
#> 
#> $actor_time_uniform
#> [1] TRUE
#> 
#> $weight
#> [1] "the_weight_var"
#> 
#> $symmetric
#> [1] TRUE
#> 
#> $isolates
#> [1] FALSE
#> 
#> $diag_to_NA
#> [1] TRUE
#> 
#> $missing_to_zero
#> [1] TRUE
#> 
#> $nodal_data
#> $nodal_data[[1]]
#> NULL
#> 
#> 
#> $dyad_data
#> $dyad_data[[1]]
#> NULL
#> 
#> 
#> $graph_data
#> $graph_data[[1]]
#> NULL
#> 
#> 
#> $netify_type
#> [1] "cross_sec"
#> 
#> $class
#> [1] "netify"

    Pre-allocation using get_netify

    get_netify can also return empty netify objects with all the proper attributes for specification later.

    empty_netlet <- netify()
attributes(empty_netlet)
#> $dim
#> [1] 1 1
#> 
#> $actor_pds
#> $actor_pds[[1]]
#> NULL
#> 
#> 
#> $actor_time_uniform
#> [1] TRUE
#> 
#> $weight
#> $weight[[1]]
#> NULL
#> 
#> 
#> $symmetric
#> [1] TRUE
#> 
#> $isolates
#> [1] FALSE
#> 
#> $diag_to_NA
#> [1] TRUE
#> 
#> $missing_to_zero
#> [1] TRUE
#> 
#> $nodal_data
#> $nodal_data[[1]]
#> NULL
#> 
#> 
#> $dyad_data
#> $dyad_data[[1]]
#> NULL
#> 
#> 
#> $graph_data
#> $graph_data[[1]]
#> NULL
#> 
#> 
#> $netify_type
#> [1] "cross_sec"
#> 
#> $class
#> [1] "netify"

    This can make it easier to incorporate get_netify and netify objects into a larger data generation process. For example, we can pre-allocate an arbitrary number of empty netify objects. We’re using the replicate function here for convenience, but any control flow statement or data generation function (e.g., for loops or lapply) will work.

    allocated_netlet <- replicate(5, netify(), simplify = FALSE)
allocated_netlet
#> [[1]]
#> ✔ Hello, you have created network data, yay!
#> • Symmetric: Yes
#> • Weighted: No
#> • Number of Unique Actors: 1
#> • Number of Edges: 0
#> • Number of Time Points: N/A
#> • Average Number of Actors: 1
#> • Nodal Attributes: N/A
#> 
#> [[2]]
#> ✔ Hello, you have created network data, yay!
#> • Symmetric: Yes
#> • Weighted: No
#> • Number of Unique Actors: 1
#> • Number of Edges: 0
#> • Number of Time Points: N/A
#> • Average Number of Actors: 1
#> • Nodal Attributes: N/A
#> 
#> [[3]]
#> ✔ Hello, you have created network data, yay!
#> • Symmetric: Yes
#> • Weighted: No
#> • Number of Unique Actors: 1
#> • Number of Edges: 0
#> • Number of Time Points: N/A
#> • Average Number of Actors: 1
#> • Nodal Attributes: N/A
#> 
#> [[4]]
#> ✔ Hello, you have created network data, yay!
#> • Symmetric: Yes
#> • Weighted: No
#> • Number of Unique Actors: 1
#> • Number of Edges: 0
#> • Number of Time Points: N/A
#> • Average Number of Actors: 1
#> • Nodal Attributes: N/A
#> 
#> [[5]]
#> ✔ Hello, you have created network data, yay!
#> • Symmetric: Yes
#> • Weighted: No
#> • Number of Unique Actors: 1
#> • Number of Edges: 0
#> • Number of Time Points: N/A
#> • Average Number of Actors: 1
#> • Nodal Attributes: N/A

    We may also want to pre-allocate netify objects with some known attributes already filled in. For example, we might know that we want a number of empty asymmetric networks even if we’re not sure yet what data will make up the structure of the netify objects. With get_netify, this is as easy as including the symmetric parameter in the function.

    allocated_weighted_netlet <- replicate(5, netify(symmetric = FALSE), simplify = FALSE)
allocated_weighted_netlet
#> [[1]]
#> ✔ Hello, you have created network data, yay!
#> • Symmetric: No
#> • Weighted: No
#> • Number of Unique Actors: 1
#> • Number of Edges: 0
#> • Number of Time Points: N/A
#> • Average Number of Actors: 1
#> • Nodal Attributes: N/A
#> 
#> [[2]]
#> ✔ Hello, you have created network data, yay!
#> • Symmetric: No
#> • Weighted: No
#> • Number of Unique Actors: 1
#> • Number of Edges: 0
#> • Number of Time Points: N/A
#> • Average Number of Actors: 1
#> • Nodal Attributes: N/A
#> 
#> [[3]]
#> ✔ Hello, you have created network data, yay!
#> • Symmetric: No
#> • Weighted: No
#> • Number of Unique Actors: 1
#> • Number of Edges: 0
#> • Number of Time Points: N/A
#> • Average Number of Actors: 1
#> • Nodal Attributes: N/A
#> 
#> [[4]]
#> ✔ Hello, you have created network data, yay!
#> • Symmetric: No
#> • Weighted: No
#> • Number of Unique Actors: 1
#> • Number of Edges: 0
#> • Number of Time Points: N/A
#> • Average Number of Actors: 1
#> • Nodal Attributes: N/A
#> 
#> [[5]]
#> ✔ Hello, you have created network data, yay!
#> • Symmetric: No
#> • Weighted: No
#> • Number of Unique Actors: 1
#> • Number of Edges: 0
#> • Number of Time Points: N/A
#> • Average Number of Actors: 1
#> • Nodal Attributes: N/A

    And what if we want to include some attribute that isn’t part of the usual netify object structure? That’s okay, too! Because netify objects are S3 classes in R, it’s easy to add arbitrary attributes to a netify network without breaking functionality. For example, let’s name one of our empty netify objects.

    named_netlet <- netify(name = 'Bob')
attributes(named_netlet)
#> $dim
#> [1] 1 1
#> 
#> $actor_pds
#> $actor_pds[[1]]
#> NULL
#> 
#> 
#> $actor_time_uniform
#> [1] TRUE
#> 
#> $weight
#> $weight[[1]]
#> NULL
#> 
#> 
#> $symmetric
#> [1] TRUE
#> 
#> $isolates
#> [1] FALSE
#> 
#> $diag_to_NA
#> [1] TRUE
#> 
#> $missing_to_zero
#> [1] TRUE
#> 
#> $nodal_data
#> $nodal_data[[1]]
#> NULL
#> 
#> 
#> $dyad_data
#> $dyad_data[[1]]
#> NULL
#> 
#> 
#> $graph_data
#> $graph_data[[1]]
#> NULL
#> 
#> 
#> $name
#> [1] "Bob"
#> 
#> $netify_type
#> [1] "cross_sec"
#> 
#> $class
#> [1] "netify"

    There’s no limit to how the get_netify object factory can be used with arbitrary attributes! Let’s add a netify object as a subnet of another netify object and see what happens.

    nested_netlet <- netify(sub_net = netify(name = 'subnet1'),
  name = 'parentnet1')
attributes(nested_netlet)
#> $dim
#> [1] 1 1
#> 
#> $actor_pds
#> $actor_pds[[1]]
#> NULL
#> 
#> 
#> $actor_time_uniform
#> [1] TRUE
#> 
#> $weight
#> $weight[[1]]
#> NULL
#> 
#> 
#> $symmetric
#> [1] TRUE
#> 
#> $isolates
#> [1] FALSE
#> 
#> $diag_to_NA
#> [1] TRUE
#> 
#> $missing_to_zero
#> [1] TRUE
#> 
#> $nodal_data
#> $nodal_data[[1]]
#> NULL
#> 
#> 
#> $dyad_data
#> $dyad_data[[1]]
#> NULL
#> 
#> 
#> $graph_data
#> $graph_data[[1]]
#> NULL
#> 
#> 
#> $sub_net
#> ✔ Hello, you have created network data, yay!
#> • Symmetric: Yes
#> • Weighted: No
#> • Number of Unique Actors: 1
#> • Number of Edges: 0
#> • Number of Time Points: N/A
#> • Average Number of Actors: 1
#> • Nodal Attributes: N/A
#> 
#> $name
#> [1] "parentnet1"
#> 
#> $netify_type
#> [1] "cross_sec"
#> 
#> $class
#> [1] "netify"
